Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Year-round autonomous sampling of methane in Arctic lakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators propose to measure methane concentrations in frozen lakes continuously throughout the Arctic winter using autonomous sampling devices, to more thoroughly address the variability in the methane flux from Arctic lakes to the atmosphere. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, the release of which from Arctic sources is poised to increase with climate warming. This project will expand upon a successful pilot study that included the initial testing of autonomous continuous fluid sampler and sensor systems. The proposed expansion will involve additional capabilities and the deployment of a sampling unit in each of six small lakes along a north-south gradient in the Mackenzie River delta in the Canadian Arctic for a nine-month period, spanning the winter season. With these data the investigators aim to characterize the physical, chemical, and microbial conditions in the water column to elucidate hydrologic, microbial, and weathering processes during the winter season, when methane builds in lake water under the ice cover. The investigators hypothesize that sudden (week, days, or even hours) releases of methane, following spring flooding and ice cover breakup, produce a distinct atmospheric flux from Arctic lakes that would otherwise be missed, since most logistically reasonable sampling occurs in the summer months when methane concentrations in these lakes are low or below detection.

The majority of methane flux to the Arctic atmosphere is estimated to come from soils and small lakes, although these estimates are based on few direct observations with large uncertainties. This proposed study, using in situ samplers and sensors, will allow an extensive microbial, gas and ion analytical program coupled with a network of physical and chemical sensor data to assess temporal conditions during winter months; to confirm fundamental processes and rates; to determine the interplay among microbial, geochemical and physical processes; and to develop a plan for a more inclusive study that takes advantage of low cost proxies for significant processes that best characterize temporal aspects of lake conditions. The project will enhance infrastructure for future research in the Arctic through the development of novel in situ sampling. The project will support several undergraduate and graduate students, providing valuable lab-based experience for students from non-research-intensive institutions. The investigators also will conduct two informal outreach activities to communicate the importance of Arctic climate change to primary school students while also teaching them about design and engineering. They also intend to work closely with Aurora College and Aurora Research Institute based in Inuvik, Canada, to engage First Nations youth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human activities during the past century have lead to a rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide, deforestation, and growth of urban areas at the expense of wetlands, forests, and grassland. These activates have fueled climate change in which the Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. The greatest affect of this warming is manifested in polar regions, where a warming shift in temperature raises surface temperatures that affect the capacity for glaciation and the thawing of permafrost. The Arctic permafrost contains methane, but as this permafrost melts it releases methane, and associated carbon dioxide. Both are green houses gases that fuel further global warming, resulting in an increase in the rate of permafrost thawing. Such changes also affect local and global ecological systems and Arctic communities.

Much of the work and the estimates for methane release from Arctic permafrost centers on studies of arctic soils. Few studies have focused on aquatic environments, which in some areas, such as the Mackenzie River delta, cover half of the Earth’s surface. Such systems tap and even larger area than surface expressions would suggest through subsurface fluid flow in taliks, which are thawed zones in permafrost beneath lakes and the surrounding area . The significance of aquatic systems for the delivery of methane to the atmosphere has grown with each study, including this one. The potential for methane production in lakes and the release of this methane to the atmosphere coupled with discrete sampling of such systems during yearly or bi-monthly sampling set the stage for our project. We deployed novel continuous fluid sampling systems for one year in six lakes that span a south-north transect from the middle of the Mackenzie River Delta to the outer delta and two lakes that reside south of the outer delta yet above the reach of the Mackenzie River.

Results from this study are striking. Methane concentration and isotopic data coupled with dissolved ion and trace element concentrations and data from sensor that measure physical parameters illustrate a profound change in the biogeochemistry of the lakes during fall months, continued change during the winter, and a sharp change in the spring. These lakes differ in their connectivity or lack of connectivity with the Mackenzie River, with the amount and flux of organic content within the sediment, the activity of subsurface hydrologic discharge that mines regional permafrost and/or delivers thermogenic methane, and the proximity (depth) to the permafrost. Yet, each lake shows the same pattern! In the fall lakes are oxic, resulting from mixing of atmospheric oxygen and microbial consumption of methane. This source of oxygen ends as atmospheric temperatures decrease and lakes become ice covered. Biogeochemical markers show the progression of electron donors, ultimately resulting in the increase in dissolved methane in lake waters. In the spring, over a period of a day or two or possibly a week, concentration of methane in lake waters drop to below detection levels. This drastic drop in concentration cannot be attributed solely by microbial consumption – there must be a component that is released to the atmosphere. Given the area of aquatic systems in the Arctic and typical concentrations of methane during ice cover, the potential flux of methane to the atmosphere during a one- to two-week period in the spring is a significant percentage of the yearly Arctic methane flux to the atmosphere. Furthermore, dissolved ion concentrations indicate an increase in some elements that exceed that expected from ice formation, indicating that spring fluids could transport trace element to the Arctic Ocean, resulting in a flux of these ions that ahs yet to be accounted for in elemental cycles in the Arctic Ocean. Elements such as manganese and iron could contribute to increased ocean productivity during the spring thaw.
